results.summary: A memorial garden has been opened at the former school of Christina Edkins, who was stabbed in a random attack in Birmingham in March.
results.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/fe8a22d1-e874-904a-a275-09fe6a7d246c"><paragraph>A memorial garden has been opened at the former school of Christina Edkins, who was stabbed in a random attack in Birmingham in March.</paragraph><paragraph>The 16-year-old was killed on a bus as she made her way to Leasowes High School in Halesowen.</paragraph><paragraph>Rugby international Phil Vickery officially opened the garden at her former school St Edmund's Catholic Primary in Spring Hill on Thursday.</paragraph><paragraph>He said the memorial would be a lasting legacy to the teenager.</paragraph><paragraph>Christina's parents were at the school for the opening, a day after Phillip Simelane, 23, was detained under the Mental Health Act after <!-- CPS Asset ID: 24394964 --><link><caption>admitting her manslaughter.</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-birmingham-24358473"/></link></paragraph><paragraph>Mary O'Friel, head teacher at St Edmunds, said the garden was the perfect way to remember Christina.</paragraph><paragraph>Young people from Birmingham took part in a debate on the problems of knife crime in the city, in the wake of recent stabbings.</paragraph><paragraph>Heather-Michaela Farrell, a friend of Joshua Ribera, who was stabbed to death in September, said more needed to be done to tackle the issue.</paragraph><paragraph>One friend of Christina Edkins, Jon Horne, said some young people carried knives almost as status symbols. </paragraph></body>
